docs.title: Instructions for users
docs.text: OSIRIS aims to facilitate your work in your individual role, be it documenting your research as a scientist, managing the college as a human resources department or creating reports for controlling. To this end, the system can be customised by the administration to suit your needs and offers different options for each role. The following sections explain functions in OSIRIS that may not be authorised for your role. This can be determined individually. Contact your administrator if you are missing functions.

docs.title: Courses
docs.text: Under Teaching modules you can create modules that allow you to combine several activities of the type Teaching. Before you can add a teaching activity, the appropriate module must be created. If you cannot find the function in the left menu, it must be activated by your administration under Settings → Functions.

docs.title: Add teaching module
docs.text:
By default, each role can add a course in OSIRIS. To do this, select Teaching modules in the menu on the left and go to Create new course. The following widget appears:

The widget to create a new course

Here you can enter the name, the module number, the institution and the person responsible. Once you have saved, your newly created module will be displayed in the list.

Your newly created learning module

docs.title: Link activity
docs.text:
There are two ways to add an activity of the type Teaching to a module. You can simply click on the in the panel of your learning module to go to the Add activities page. The Teaching type and the appropriate module have already been automatically selected here. Alternatively, you can go to the Add activity page and select the type teaching. Here you have to search for your module by name or module number.

Form to add a teaching activity

In addition to the module, you must specify further parameters:

  • Teaching category: Here you can select the type of teaching activity. You can choose between Lecture, Internship, Seminar or various combinations of these
  • Supervisor with SWS: Enter one or more people who will supervise this teaching activity here. It is important to specify the semester hours per week and whether the person is affiliated with your institute
  • Time span:** You can enter the dates for your module here. If it only takes one day, you can leave the last field empty. You also have a selection of semesters to the left, which you can click on to make it easier to fill in the time span

Courses can also be linked to research areas. The areas available for selection can be found at the bottom of the form.

You can add several teaching activities to a module. The number of linked activities is displayed on the teaching module board (see above). You can display these in short form by clicking on the number.

Module table with the linked teaching activities

A module can only be deleted if no links exist yet.

docs.title: Events in OSIRIS
docs.text: OSIRIS can be used for the centralised management of upcoming conferences, congresses or other events. Events are a function that must be activated by the administration. If you cannot find a tab for events in the menu on the left and/or do not have the rights to add new events, please contact your administration.

docs.title: Create new event
docs.text:
To create a new event, you can either use the drop-down menu at the top left for Add activity or select the events page on the left in the menu and click on Add event.

A form will open in which you must enter the following information:

  • Short title of the event
  • Type: You can choose between Local, National or International. The selection can be customised via Vocabulary
  • Date of the event
  • Location of the event

Form to add an event in OSIRIS

You can also enter further details here, such as a longer title or a URL for the event.

If Research areas or Keywords are activated in your instance, you can link your event to existing ones in the lower section of the form.

If activated, you can also link your event to research areas or keywords

Your created event looks like this

As you can see, you can of course edit or delete your event. To the right of the display shown here is the description you have entered or the longer title of the event.

docs.title: Participation in events
docs.text:
All OSIRIS users are shown the events entered on the right-hand side of the start page. By clicking on the Interested and Participant buttons, users can record their participation or interest in the event.

This is how the events entered in OSIRIS are displayed on the start page of each user

The number on the buttons shows you how many users have already registered their participation or interest. If you go to the event entry, you will also see the names of the people.

On the event page, you can see which people from your organisation are still interested in or even attending the event

docs.title: Link an event to an activity
docs.text:
At the bottom of the event page, you have the option of linking the event to activities.

Here you can add an activity to the event

By clicking on Add contribution you will be forwarded directly to the Add activity page. The activity type lecture is preselected here and already filled in appropriately for the event.

docs.title: Warnings and messages
docs.text:
There are various messages that you can receive as a user in OSIRIS. They show you where you need to take action. You can see whether you currently have a message by the bell symbol at the top right of your profile. With one click, you can see all messages in an extra window with a direct link to the respective pages.

Display of the current messages

docs.title: Verification of authorships
docs.text:
Sometimes other scientists or members of the institute add scientific activities in which you were also involved. The system tries to assign them automatically, which is why you will receive a message to confirm your authorship. Make sure that you really belong to the activity and that your name is spelt correctly and affiliated with the institute.

The confirmation of the activity can be requested again if the activity has been changed by other people, be it correction of spelling mistakes or the deposit of a document.

You must confirm a change to the activity again. On the right you can see the change made and the comment of the person making the change (if available)

There are five buttons below the question as to whether this is your activity:

  • green tick: This allows you to confirm the activity if you were affiliated with the institute at the time
  • Pin: This confirms that this is your activity, but that you were not affiliated with the institute at the time.
  • Red cross: You reject the activity and thus the authorship
  • Pen: Takes you to the page where you can edit the activity
  • Arrow: Takes you to the extended view of the activity

docs.title: Online ahead of print
docs.text:
Online ahead of print means that the publication is already available online, but the actual publication in an issue is still pending. An example of this is the NAR Database Issue, where publications are already available online in September or October, although the issue is not published until the following January.

These publications cannot be included in the reports. They are included in OSIRIS so as not to lose sight of them and because they represent achievements that have already been made. In such cases, OSIRIS regularly asks whether the publication has now been published. Only then can it be included in the reporting.

The bibliographic data must be checked again. The Epub box must be unchecked and the publication date is usually also adjusted. It can also happen that the bibliographic data itself changes, for example the page number. Therefore, please check carefully that all data is correct.

docs.title: Student degree
docs.text:
To ensure that final theses always have the correct status and completion date, OSIRIS issues a warning if these theses are still "in progress" even though the completion date is in the past.

Warning to check the status of the thesis

Please check whether the thesis has already been completed. If this is the case, you can adjust the status accordingly and enter the end date. If the thesis is still "in progress", you can simply extend the date of the thesis. OSIRIS will ask you again in due course whether the thesis has been successfully completed.

docs.title: Release quarter
docs.text: If this function has been activated by the administration, OSIRIS will ask you at the end of each quarter to check your activities and release the quarter for controlling. You can find more information about the quarterly reports here and here.

docs.title: Activities without end date
docs.text: If you are a member of committees, editorial boards or the like, OSIRIS will remind you every quarter that this activity exists and ask you for confirmation. If you click on yes, you will not be reminded of this activity until the next quarter. If you click on no, you will be redirected to the edit page of the activity where you can set the end date.

docs.title: Organisations in OSIRIS
docs.text:
Under People → Organisations you can store partner institutes or other institutions in OSIRIS and link them to content in OSIRIS.

Overview of all added organisations

docs.title: Add new organisation
docs.text:
You can create a new organisation in OSIRIS via Create new organisation. If this button is not displayed, you do not have the rights for this action - please contact the administration.

You can create a new organisation here

You can enter the organisation manually or using the ROR ID (Research Organisation Registry). You can simply search for the institute on the ROR page and copy the link into OSIRIS. OSIRIS will then fill in all subjects automatically. If you cannot find the organisation you want to add in the ROR directory, you can also add it manually. This requires the name, country and type of organisation, with a drop-down menu suggesting options for the type. To be able to display the organisation on the cooperation map, you can also enter the exact coordinates here.

If you create a new infrastructure and select Collaborative infrastructure, you can also add further organisations here using a simple search field in OSIRIS. If you add an organisation here, it will automatically be listed on the organisations page.

docs.title: Links
docs.text: Stored organisations are mainly used to display projects and infrastructures and to correctly specify the cooperation partners. For both infrastructures and applications, you can search directly for the organisation or use the ROR ID. All links are listed on the organisation's OSIRIS page. Here you can also edit the organisation afterwards.

docs.title: Research areas
docs.text:
Research areas can be used in OSIRIS to define the thematic focus of scientific research by researchers or research groups. The function must be activated by your administration under Settings → Functions.

Note

We use the term "research areas" here, but the administrator can customise this term in the settings. Therefore, you may see a different name in the OSIRIS interface instead. If you are unsure, look for an icon that looks like a puzzle piece.

By default, only the administrator has the right to create a new research area. If your role has been granted the right, you will find a button on the research area page with the option Add new area.

docs.title: Create new research area
docs.text:
When you create a new research area, it is immediately assigned a unique ID. You must also give your research area a name. The form also gives you the option of assigning a colour to the research area, adding a subtitle and a description.

Form to create a new research area

If you click on save, you will be taken to the page of your newly created research area. Here you can customise it by uploading your own image and editing the name and description.

Your newly created research area page

You will find the option to delete the research area under the General tab. This will cause all links to be lost.

docs.title: Create shortcuts
docs.text:
The research areas you have created will now appear in different areas in OSIRIS in order to link them to people, activities or organisational units.

This is what your research areas for linking look like. You can create a link to the respective page by clicking on it

To link a person to a research area, go to the profile → Edit profile → Research. Here you can click on the areas that you want to link to this person. After you have saved, the selected areas will be displayed on the profile with a button that leads directly to the research area.

This is how the linked research area is displayed in the profile

When you add a new activity in OSIRIS, the research areas are displayed below for you to choose from. You can also link activities to the areas afterwards. The filter options for All activities have been expanded to include the research areas.

You can also link Events, Organisational units and Infrastructures to research areas on the respective pages and filter them accordingly.

This is what the links to research units look like on the organisational units page. The coloured dots also show you the respective links for the persons

All links can also be found on the respective research area page. If you have linked more than two activities, an author graph and a word cloud will be created automatically.

docs.title: Quality workflows
docs.text:
1.6.0

Thanks to the workflow function, you will always be notified in your individual user role in OSIRIS when an action is required of you. Quality workflows can map entire inspection and approval processes and are managed by the administration. If an action or a check is required from you, this will be displayed in the menu on the left under Reviews. You can find more detailed explanations of the process here.

docs.title: All activities
docs.text:
If you select All activities in the menu on the left, you will see an overview of all entries in OSIRIS.

The All activities page with an overview of all entries in OSIRIS

This page offers you simple options for filtering the entries on the right. You can also use the top bar of the table to sort the entries by Quarter, Type or alphabetically by clicking on Activity. To export the table, you can choose between Excel and csv format, or simply copy the table.

To create a more customised list of entries, you can use the advanced search.

Next to each activity you will find an arrow that takes you to the expanded view of the entry. If you want to create a list of entries for export without the advanced search, you can use the shopping cart icon to the right of the arrow.

At the top left you will see the button that takes you to Statistics. Here you can find various tables relating to the entries in a specific report period in OSIRIS.

If you have the role of Admin or Editor or have been assigned the right to block activities, you will find the button for this directly next to the statistics button. If the button is not displayed, you have not been granted this right.

docs.title: Advanced activity search
docs.text:
To the video

You can search the All activities page quickly and easily using the search bar at the top left. If a simple search is not enough, you can perform an advanced search, which you will find directly next to the search bar.

docs.title: Search with operators
docs.text:
The advanced search in OSIRIS offers you a variety of options for filtering the entries in the database. You can add further criteria using the New rule button. You can use the AND/OR buttons above the category field to determine the dependency of your search fields. If you would like to use a combination of AND/OR, you can add further fields and create a new dependency using the new group button at the top right.

Example of an advanced search:: This search will show you all activities that are a Journal Article AND have an Impact Factor greater than 2 AND were published in 2025 OR 2024.

You can remove any search field from your search using the delete button to the right of it.

You can use the Select columns function to add or remove as many columns as you like to the results table of your search. If you click on the button, a widget opens which shows you all available columns and which you can select with a click. Columns that are not available are greyed out.

The add column widget allows you to add any columns to your results table.

This is what your table looks like when you have added the columns "Journal" and "Impact Factor" in the widget.

docs.title: Save search queries
docs.text:
You can save your current search with the Saved queries button and use it again and again. A widget opens, which displays previously saved searches and allows you to give your current search a name. After you have saved the search, you must reload the page before you can find your search again in the saved queries.

In the "Saved queries" widget, you can see all your saved searches and can give your current search a name. By clicking on a saved search, you can view the information and delete the search.

docs.title: Aggregate a search
docs.text:
Next to the "Select column" function you will find the Aggregate button. You can use this function to create an overview table of the number of entries in your results table. If you aggregate by year, for example, the table will show you the number of journal articles per year. The aggregation table depends on your current search.

Here you aggregate the search shown above by "Year". The table shows you the number of entries per year.

docs.title: Copy search and continue using it
docs.text:
Click on the Show filter button to display the MongoDB code for your filter. You can use this code to share your search with others or to reuse it yourself. For example, you can use the code to filter the activities in the Report template function. Here, for example, you can see the code for the search performed above.

{"$and":[{"subtype":"article"},{"impact":{"$gt":2}},{"$or":[{"year":2025},{"year":2024}]}]}

docs.title: Expert mode
docs.text: Next to the orange "Apply" button you will find the Expert mode. Here you can enter your own MongoDB commands to search OSIRIS.

docs.title: Download collection
docs.text:
If you do not want to use the advanced search option to create a customised list of activities, you can use the shopping cart on the All Activities page to add entries to it.

List of all activities with selected entries that have been added to the shopping cart

On the left of your menu, the number of selected entries is displayed in orange next to the link to the Cart.

Once you have selected all entries, they will be displayed under Shopping trolley. Here you have various options for downloading the list.

View of the shopping cart with different download options

You can choose here whether your name, all names of affiliates or no name should be highlighted in the exported view. You also have the option to download the list in Bibtex format. To remove entries, simply click the cross to the right of the activity.

docs.title: Advanced view of activities
docs.text:
In the extended view of an activity, you can view all details, edit, block or even delete the activity (if you have the rights to do so).

The extended view of an activity

In addition to the title and the authors, you will see initial information about the entry below. Here you will see the date, whether at least one author is affiliated with your institute and whether the authors are all from your institute (Institutional), cooperated with other scientists and were leading (Cooperative (Leading)) or contributing (Cooperative (Contributing)). In the row, you also have the option of displaying the visibility of this activity in the portfolio. If you leave the activity visible, you can highlight it by clicking on the button next to it.

All the important buttons on this page are explained in more detail below:

  1. collect: Use this button to add the activity to your shopping cart
  2. download: This button offers you the Word or BibTex format for download. You can also customise which authors are highlighted
  3. preview: A preview of how this activity will look externally in the portfolio
  4. general: Here you can see all the details entered for the activity and the fields that have not been filled in by the author
  5. co-authors: A graphic about your co-authors and the organisational units to which they belong

  6. link project: A widget opens where you can link existing projects to this activity. If the activity is already linked to one, it will be displayed here

    Widget to link projects to the activity

  7. infrastructures: Here you can link existing infrastructures to the activity

  8. upload file: A widget opens which allows you to upload relevant documents. Once you have uploaded a file, the button changes to Files and you will find your documents here and can add more

  9. history: All changes that have been made to the activity are listed here.

    Listing of the changes, together with comments, the person who made the changes and the date

  10. authors: In the list you can see which of the authors have already confirmed the activity. If changes are made to the activity, the activity must be confirmed again by the authors. You can also edit the list of authors here

    Here you can add authors to the activity, change the order or remove authors

  11. delete activity: Whether you can delete the activity depends on whether you have been assigned the right. If the activity has been locked, only editors or admins can edit or delete activities

If you have been assigned the right, you can see another button next to the history that takes you to the raw data. By default, only administrators and editors can see this.

docs.title: Pivot table
docs.text:
1.4.1

The pivot table is a powerful tool for analysing and visualising large amounts of data. It allows you to quickly aggregate, filter and sort data to recognise patterns and trends. You can find the pivot table in the "Visualisation" section.

docs.title: Create content
docs.text:
OSIRIS offers you the opportunity to document all your scientific activities and link them to research areas, organisational units or projects. On your profile page you will find a button on the left which will take you directly to the Add activity page. The button is also displayed in orange in the menu area on the left.

The Add activity page with the listed activity categories in OSIRIS

You have various options for adding an activity in OSIRIS, which are explained below.

docs.title: Add content via search in Pubmed
docs.text:
You can add publications via a search in Pubmed. To do this, you can use various search parameters on the page.

Search parameters to search Pubmed for publications

When you perform the search, all publications found will be listed. You can transfer them to the Add activities form using the . Please check all the transferred values again here. Don't forget to mark the affiliated persons by double-clicking on them. If there are entries in the search that are already stored in OSIRIS, this is indicated by a red border and the Duplicate flag.

docs.title: Add content via DOI
docs.text:
If you have a DOI (Digital Object Identifier) for your publication, you can enter it directly in the search bar. OSIRIS will then fill in the form automatically. Again, please check the values and tick the affiliated authors. If the associated publication is already stored in OSIRIS, you will also be shown a warning regarding a duplicate.

Warning about a duplicate in the DOI search

docs.title: Add content manually
docs.text: You can of course also enter all your activities manually in OSIRIS. Several activity categories with different activity types are available for this purpose. Once you have selected the appropriate type of activity, a form will appear for you to complete. Mandatory fields are always marked with a red star. The forms depend on the activity you have selected and can be customised by the administration.

docs.title: Format title
docs.text:
Field to format the title

Make sure that the spelling and formatting of the title match the original work. The following formatting is supported: italics, underline, superscript and subscript. There are also shortcuts for the most common Greek special characters.

docs.title: Add authors
docs.text:
Your name is automatically added as an affiliate in the author list when you create a new activity.

Author field to add more names

You can add further names using the Add author field. If these names are stored in OSIRIS, they will be displayed in a drop-down menu. If you have added several names, you can change the order using drag & drop. It is also important to mark all affiliated authors accordingly by double-clicking on them. Affiliated authors are marked and the abbreviation of the institute appears in front of the name. If you want to remove authors again, simply click on the red cross behind the name. If authors are employees of your institute but were not at the time of the activity, they must not be marked accordingly.

docs.title: Link research areas
docs.text:
The available research areas are displayed at the end of the form (if this function is activated). With one click, you can link your activity to one or more areas. This can be adjusted afterwards. The link will be displayed accordingly in the existing activity.

Activity with the linked research areas

docs.title: Link organisational units
docs.text:
If the activity falls within the period in which you are assigned to an organisational unit, it is automatically linked to this unit. The link is displayed at the bottom of the extended activity view.

Linking the activity to an organisational unit

docs.title: Add note
docs.text: Under the research areas, you also have the option to leave a note for your co-authors and/or for the administration. This note will only be displayed in the created activity for the persons concerned.

docs.title: Drafts
docs.text:
1.6.0

OSIRIS offers you the option of saving drafts for your entries. When you add a new activity, there is now a Save as draft button next to the Save button on the form. If the button is not displayed, please contact your administrator. They can activate the function.

Button at the end of a form to save drafts

If you save an activity as a draft, your co-authors will not be informed. You can therefore still make changes here at your leisure. Only when you save the draft as an activity will your co-authors be notified. You can find all your drafts at the top left of the Add activity page.

You will find a button for your existing drafts at the top left of the add activity page

If you click on the button, all your drafts will be displayed.

Display all your drafts

Here you can either display your drafts or switch directly to the editor to complete your entry.

docs.title: edit content
docs.text: Once you have created the activity, you can edit it as long as it has not yet been locked.

docs.title: Edit authors
docs.text:
You can use the author editor to make further settings for the authors.

The author editor to make further settings

You can use the dots on the left to change the order of the names using drag & drop. You can set the position of the authors separately via a drop-down menu. You can specify both the affiliation to the institute and to the organisational unit for each name. Of course, you can also add more names to the list or remove names using the bin symbol on the right. The surname is a mandatory field, the first name can be omitted as an option. In the example shown above, you can see that you do not have to belong to the institute to link the activities to the user profile. The second author in the list is assigned to a user account, but was not affiliated with the institute at the time of the work. The activity is linked to the account and is displayed in his profile, but he is not marked as an affiliated author in the report and does not receive any coins for the activity. You can also add authors who do not have a user account in OSIRIS.

docs.title: Edit journal
docs.text:
Journals are relevant for Journal articles and Reviews & Editorials.

For reasons of standardisation, a journal cannot be entered as a free text field. Instead, the following module can be found:

Field for journals and reviews & editorials to specify the journal

If you click on the field, you can search for a journal by name or preferably by ISSN number. If there are several journals for the search used, they will be listed and you can add one of them to your activity by ticking the green box.

Search for a journal

If the journal you are looking for is not found, you can also search the OpenAlex catalogue using the button below.

docs.title: Upload files
docs.text:
You can store important documents for each activity in OSIRIS. To do this, go to the expanded view of the activity and click on Upload file to access the following widget:

Widget for uploading a file for an activity and for downloading and deleting existing files

If files have already been added to this activity, the button will be displayed as files with the number of documents stored. If you click on the button, the existing files are displayed. On the right is a button for uploading further files, which takes you to the widget. All uploaded documents are displayed under All files, which you can also download and delete here. Under Add files you can upload new documents by clicking on Attach a file. These must not exceed a maximum size of 16 MB and should be in a standard format if possible. Good examples are PDF (preferred), PPTX, XLSX, DOCX. Once you have selected the file, all you have to do is click on Upload to upload it.

docs.title: Editor comments
docs.text:
When an activity is edited, OSIRIS offers the possibility to leave a comment regarding the changes to all co-authors.

Possibility to comment on a change to the activity for the other authors

This field only appears if you are editing an existing activity. If you think that your changes are too minimal to require review by the co-authors, you can tick the appropriate box at the bottom.

This way, your co-authors will see the change with your comment

When your co-authors are notified, they will receive a message showing your changes and your comment. In this message, they can confirm whether the assignment is correct, whether they were not yet affiliated when the activity took place, or even reject the authorship. With the pencil button you can edit the activity yourself, the arrow button leads to the extended view of the activity.

docs.title: Copy activity
docs.text:
OSIRIS offers you the option of creating copies for certain types of activities, allowing you to quickly create recurring activities with slight changes (e.g. date or event). Copying is possible for all activity types except publications.

Button in the extended activity view to create a copy of the activity

This function is particularly useful if, for example, you are presenting talks or posters at several conferences. This way, you only have to adjust the date and/or location and do not have to create the activity from scratch.

docs.title: Indexing of entries
docs.text:
To better categorise entries in OSIRIS and make them easier to find by topic, you can link activities, events and projects with keywords. This function must be switched on by the administration. The keywords are also specified by the administration. So if you are missing a word, please contact your admins. Further explanations can be found here.

To add keywords to an activity, the administration must add the keywords data field to the form of the respective activity type via the form builder.

This is what the keyword data field looks like in the activity form

The Keywords data field appears as a drop-down menu in the activity form, from which the user can select any number of words. These are then listed in the completed activity view, separated by a comma.

Under All activities you can now also filter the activities according to these keywords.

You can also link events to keywords. When you add a new event, you will find the drop-down menu with the existing keywords under the research areas and can select several matching words. As with the activities, you can also filter by keywords here.

To link projects with keywords, the administration must add the keywords field to the various phases of the project. This is possible under Contents → Projects. The respective type of project can be selected and edited here. The selection of the optional fields can be found on the second page of the project settings.

docs.title: Infrastructures
docs.text:
1.4.1

Like projects, research infrastructures are a separate entity in OSIRIS that must be activated centrally. If you would like to maintain research infrastructures in OSIRIS, but this function is not yet activated, please contact your OSIRIS administrator. They can find the instructions for activation here.

Note

We use the term "research infrastructures" here, but the administrator can customise this term in the settings. Therefore, you may see a different name in the OSIRIS interface instead. If you are unsure, look for an icon that looks like a transparent cube.

Research infrastructures are centralised resources such as equipment, facilities, data, libraries or virtual platforms that are made available to scientists to enable and facilitate research and promote innovation.

docs.title: Persons in OSIRIS
docs.text: OSIRIS can be used not only to keep an overview of all activities in the institute, but also to manage employees and organise departments. Under People you can view the entire staff registered in OSIRIS and search through them using various tools. You can influence which keywords or expertise you can be found with in OSIRIS by editing your profile accordingly.

docs.title: Filter by organisational unit
docs.text:
To the right of the listed profiles, you will find the option to search the college by organisational units. If you click on an available organisational unit, all profiles in OSIRIS that belong to this unit will be displayed.

Application of the organisational unit filter

docs.title: Filter by keywords
docs.text:
If your administration has defined keywords, you can use these to search profiles. However, users must also use them in their profile. You have two options for searching with keywords: To the right of the profiles, you will find another one for the keywords under the organisational unit filter. You can also find a button for keywords next to the search bar above the profiles. On this page you will find all existing keywords with the people who have entered them in their profile.

Search for people using keywords

Clicking on a name will take you to the person's profile. If you are missing keywords in OSIRIS, please contact your administrator.

docs.title: Filter by expertise
docs.text: There is no predefined list of expertise provided by the administration, each person can add a new expertise. If you click on the Expertise button, you will find a list of all terms used by users and the corresponding names. Here, too, you can click on the name to access the corresponding profile. You can also search the expertise for a specific term.

docs.title: Advanced search
docs.text:
As with the activities, you can also use an advanced search to filter the people. You can use various search criteria such as first name/last name, room or keywords with the operators AND/OR to search the college.

The advanced people search with two search criteria

docs.title: Export
docs.text: You can export a list of the college in Excel format by clicking on the Excel button to the right of the keywords button. You can reduce the list to be exported using the filters available on the right.

docs.title: Manage guests
docs.text: Every user can enter a guest in OSIRIS by default. The entry should always be made by the supervisor. Every newly registered guest receives an ID, which you can find at the top left of the form to be filled in. In principle, only guests that you have created yourself are visible to you. However, this can be changed by the administrator by assigning rights.

docs.title: Register guests
docs.text:
If you select Guests in the menu on the left, you can open the form for a new registration by clicking the Register new guest button at the top.

Form for registering a new guest in OSIRIS

When registering a guest, you must specify the duration of the stay, which you can also extend later. If you are not looking after the guest yourself, you can select another person to do so here. You must also specify the purpose of the stay and the funding. You can choose from a number of options in the drop-down menu. For financing, you can also select Other and then enter an individual value. In addition to the mandatory information, you can enter further options for the guest in the following section.

Optional information that you can enter for guests

Here you can enter the guest's name, contact information or school/university/company.

docs.title: Extend or cancel stay
docs.text:
People who have created the guest and/or who have been specified as the supervisor can extend or cancel the guest's stay.

The guest's stay can be cancelled with one click - this can also be cancelled again afterwards. The stay can also be extended

docs.title: Deposit documents and chip
docs.text:
If you have the rights to view and edit guest documents, you can link another person to the guest in addition to the carer.

Further options that can be specified for the guest. This is only possible if you have the rights for the guest documents

You can also store documents here and enter a chip number if access chips are issued to guests at your institution.

Storing a chip number

Here you can also specify when the guest was registered and when the chip was returned.

docs.title: In the activity overview
docs.text:
If you find an activity in OSIRIS that should be assigned to you, but you are not listed as an author or contributor, you can claim it. To do this, go to the overview page of the activity, where you will find a table with all authors in the general information on the right-hand side.

If you are not yet assigned to the activity, you will see the Claim button next to authors who are not linked to any users. If you click on it, a dropdown will open explaining what exactly happens when you claim the activity. Click on Claim again to assign your user profile to the author and the activity will appear in your activity overview. The author's name is also linked to your user name so that future activities can be automatically assigned to you.

Claim activity via the button next to the author's name

docs.title: About your profile
docs.text:
You can also claim activities via your profile. To do this, go to your start page and click on the Claim activities.

On the following page you will find a list of all the activities you can claim. They will be searched for using all the names stored in your profile. Please note that only matches are shown where the author is not yet linked to a user profile.

List of activities that you can claim

Next to each activity you will find a checkbox. At the top of the table there is also an option to tick all the boxes at once. Once you have selected the desired activities, click on the Claim selected activities button to assign the activities to your profile.

docs.title: E-Mail-Digest
docs.text:
1.6.0

With this new function, you can receive emails from OSIRIS at regular intervals informing you about pending activities, messages and possible updates. This function must be switched on centrally by the administration. An explanation can be found here.

In your profile, you can decide for yourself how often you receive emails. To do this, go to Edit profile on your start page and then select Contact.

Here you can determine how often you receive mails from OSIRIS

The mails contain the following information:

  • Pending notifications for expired quarters (if relevant).
  • open activities & issues,
  • new messages,
  • pending reviews,
  • system news & updates (only if other notifications are also available).

Example of a digest mail from OSIRIS

docs.title: My activities
docs.text:
Unlike on the My Year page, your activities are sorted by quarter here, not by category.

The My activities page lists all your activities sorted by quarter

You have several options here to filter or search your activities. You can also export the list as an Excel or csv file.

docs.title: Quarter view
docs.text:
If your role has the rights to the quarterly overview, a graphic and direct links will be added to your start page.

Quarterly overview on your dashboard

The graphic shows you how many researchers have already released the past quarter. If you click on Details, you will see a list of all registered researchers and whether they have already been approved or not.

docs.title: Scientist view
docs.text:
On the "My year" page, users can gain an overview of all their own research activities for a year and confirm on a quarterly basis that all information is correct and complete. The data is transmitted to the reporters.

The My year page shows you your previous activities on a timeline and marks the current quarter

You can change the selected quarter at the top right. If you have not yet confirmed the selected quarter, you will be prompted to do so by the green button. If there are still unconfirmed activities in this quarter, you will be asked to confirm or adjust them if necessary.

Message for the quarterly release with a list of the missing checks and the subsequent view of the activities to be confirmed

  1. confirmation of the activity
  2. the activity belongs to you, but you were not yet affiliated with the institute
  3. rejection of the activity
  4. edit the activity
  5. view activity

Once you have processed all warnings, you can confirm the quarter or release it for reporting.

The request for you to release the quarter

Below the timeline you will find all your activities, organised by category. The activities of the selected quarter are also marked here and you will be notified if an activity has not yet been confirmed by you.

For example, if you have selected the 3rd quarter, the first publication will be highlighted. You will also see a warning that the publication below has not yet been confirmed by you

On the right, you can use the arrow to display the activity directly, add the activity to the shopping basket to download several collections or edit the activity by clicking on the pencil. If activated by the admin, the number of coins you have collected per activity will also be displayed. If you notice that an activity is missing from a category, you can simply add it using the .

docs.title: Your start page
docs.text:
On your start page you will find all important information and links at a glance.

OSIRIS start page

The different buttons on your start page are explained below:

  1. add activity: This button directs you immediately to the Add activity page
  2. my activities: Here you will see the list of all activities that are linked to you
  3. my year: You will be redirected to the my year page, which gives you an overview of your activities using a timeline. The current quarter is highlighted in yellow, as are the associated activities. Further explanations can be found here
  4. preview: Here you can see a preview of what your profile will look like in the portfolio
  5. my achievements: If Achievements have been activated by the administration you can see yours here
  6. edit profile: Here you can edit your profile. You will find more details in the next section 7 Claim activity: If you find activities in OSIRIS that should be assigned to you, you can claim them here
  7. export CV: OSIRIS offers you the option of downloading a list of all entries for further use here

Further direct links are available in the next bar.

  • News: Shows you the latest entries within your institute in OSIRIS
  • General: Shows your profile with all the information you have entered
  • Publications: A list of your publications with the graphics Impact Factor Histogram and Role in Publications
  • Coauthors: Shows you your co-author network over the last five years
  • Activities: Listing of all activities (except publications), represented by a bar chart over the years
  • Word cloud: A word cloud image based on the title and abstract of publications you are linked to in OSIRIS

There are additional buttons at the top right of your start page.

At the top right you will find buttons for general settings

The bell button shows you notifications regarding updates, name mentions etc. Next to it you will find the option to set the language of OSIRIS to English. The accessibility button allows you to customise the site to your needs. If you have been assigned the maintenance of another profile, you can find the corresponding name by clicking on the last button in the drop-down menu.

docs.title: Edit profile
docs.text: Here you can make all the settings relating to your profile. Always remember to click on Update when you make changes.

docs.title: Personal
docs.text:
On this page you can change your name or enter variations of your name to improve author matching for publications. For example, if you have published scientific publications with a different name, you can enter it here so that the publications can be linked to your profile.

Enter variations of your name for author matching

If you change your name, your name will be changed in your profile and future activities will be labelled with this name, but existing entries will retain the old version.

docs.title: Organisation
docs.text: Here you can enter organisational details, such as your room number or your current position in the institute. If the administration has specified roles, you can choose from a list here. If this is not the case, you can enter the role as free text.

docs.title: Research
docs.text: To describe your research, you can choose from a list of keywords provided by the administration. You can specify your expertise and research interests more individually using the free text fields. If you click in the field to add an expertise, you will be shown all the terms already available so that you can also choose from these.

docs.title: Biography
docs.text: Here you can map your career by entering your stations in the form provided. Simply add a contribution if you would like to enter several stations.

docs.title: Portfolio
docs.text: Portfolio is the external presentation of institutional research and presents your profile with all your achievements, from publications to third-party funded projects and research activities. On this page you can decide for yourself what information is shown to the outside world or whether your profile is shown at all. You can also enter an alternative e-mail address.

docs.title: Contact
docs.text: Here you can enter your contact details as well as your ORCID and Google Scholar ID.

docs.title: Account
docs.text: You can transfer the maintenance of your profile to another user. This is useful if you are away for a longer period of time, for example. This person can access all your private details and settings, as well as make and delete changes.

docs.title: Settings
docs.text: Here you can make minor settings, such as whether the coins and achievements (if activated) are visible on your profile or not.

docs.title: Introduction to projects
docs.text:
1.2.2

The project function allows you to document and manage your projects in all phases (Applied for, Approved, Rejected and Ongoing). You can also link projects to activities and keywords and add users.

If the Applications/Projects button is not displayed on the left-hand side of the menu, this function has not been activated by the administration or your user role has not been granted the rights for the functions. If you are missing something here, please contact your administrator.

If you have access to the admin area, you can customise the forms for your projects. Details can be found here.

Here you can also set whether a project category must be created as a request or whether users can create projects directly.

docs.title: Manage applications
docs.text:
Once you have created a new application, there are three different ways to manage it. You can see these by clicking on Applied for in the top right-hand corner.

Application status](screenshots/application_status.png)

There are three different ways to manage your application further

Once you have changed the status of your application, you can no longer cancel it.

docs.title: Request rejected
docs.text:
If your application has been rejected, you can note this in OSIRIS and adjust the status.

This page opens when you select rejected

Here you can enter the date of the rejection and a comment on the process. The overview of your application will expand to include another tab in red, under which you will find information about the rejection.

docs.title: Application withdrawn
docs.text: You also have the option of filing a withdrawn application in OSIRIS. If you select Withdrawn, a form similar to that for a rejection will open, in which you can enter the date and the reason for the rejection.

docs.title: Application approved
docs.text:
If your application has been approved, you can adjust the status accordingly. As a few details often change after approval, selecting Approved will open a form in which you can adjust them.

Here you can change the title and start date of your application before saving it as approved

If you are missing any fields here, you can contact your administration, as they can customise the form.

After you have customised the status, the page of your application will also change here.

The page of your application after it has been approved

You can edit the respective status by selecting either Application or Approval and then clicking on Edit current status. As you can see, another button has been added to the left of this one, which you can use to convert your application into a project. Again, a form will open which can be customised by the administration. After you have saved, you will see a link to the newly created project.

Here you will find the link to the corresponding project

Your application will now also be listed under Projects. You can now link activities and cooperation partners on your project page. You can also find the direct link to the corresponding application here.

Excerpt from the project page

This page shows you all the important details about your project, such as duration and time period. You can still edit these if anything changes.

docs.title: Create sub-project
docs.text:
On the project page, you also have the option to create sub-projects. The form that opens when you click on Create sub-project corresponds to that of the parent project category and is already partially filled out. Fields such as short title or project start and end are adjusted according to the parent project. However, you can also change these fields. Once you have saved your sub-project, it will be listed as an additional tile in the projects.

Your sub-project is marked as a branch of the parent charity project

The subproject will be listed on the project page in the future, just as the parent project is shown on the subproject page.

docs.title: Create a new application or project
docs.text:
If your role has been assigned the rights to create new applications/projects, you can use both the Applications and the Projects button on the left-hand side of the menu and select Create new application or Create new project. You will always be shown all available project categories. If you select one of the categories, you will see whether you need to create an application first.

Projects for which no application is required beforehand are created directly as projects

For example, the project category charity projects must first be created as a request, the category no request needed is created directly as a project.

Once you have selected one of the categories, a form with mandatory and optional fields will open. Once you have filled these in, you can create your request by saving it.

This is what your new application looks like in the first phase (applied for)

Via Edit current status you can edit the current status of the application - in this case Applied for.

You can also download the application and save it as a Word or JSON file.

You have the option to delete the application. Be aware that all links to people, activities or other information will be lost and this step cannot be undone. If the delete button is not displayed, you do not have the rights to delete applications or projects.

If the application has been processed in its current status, this will be displayed under the History tab.

History with details of changes to the application

Under the Documents tab, you can add various documents to your application and thus make them available centrally for all parties involved.

As you can see, your project is also automatically added to organisational units. This depends on the people who have been linked to the project.

docs.title: Link projects
docs.text: As in other areas of OSIRIS, you can link projects with people involved, co-operation partners or activities.

docs.title: Link co-operation partners
docs.text:
If you want to add cooperation partners to your project via the Cooperation partners** button, the following page will open:

Page to add co-operation partners with various setting options

There are various ways to add partners. You can use the ROR-ID, search directly for the institute or add it manually. With the first two methods, OSIRIS fills in most of the fields automatically. If you add an institute manually, the following fields must be filled in:

  • Institute name
  • Role: You have the choice between Partner, Coordinator and Participant.
  • Type:** You also have a choice of terms here, depending on ROR metadata
  • Country code:** Type in the first letters of the country to select the country code

To display all your co-operation partners on a world map, you can also enter the exact coordinates of the partner institute here.

This is what the page with your cooperation partners for your project looks like

In future, the links to the institutions will be listed on the respective organisation page. In addition, institutions that you add manually here will be included in the list of organisations.

docs.title: Link activities
docs.text:
You can link your projects to registered activities in OSIRIS. If you go to Link activity, a widget opens with which you can search for and select activities. However, the link can also be created via the activities page. If you select an activity, you can select the Link project button on the page.

Widget on the activity page to link a project

Here you can search for the available projects in OSIRIS and link them to the activity. Select the project, click on the button to the right (Add project) and confirm your selection.

docs.title: Add people
docs.text:
You can add people in different roles to both applications and projects. In both cases, you can enter additional people as applicants in the creation form. However, you can also edit the persons afterwards on the right under Project employees.

Here you can add more people to your application or project and assign them different roles

If you have added several people to your application and convert it into a project after approval, they will automatically be linked to the project. However, people who are subsequently added to the project will not be linked to the application retroactively. You can assign different roles to the people in the project from the drop-down menu. If you are missing a role, please contact your administration. They can adjust the Vocabulary for project roles. You can also specify the organisational unit for which the persons in this project are active in the table on the right. If a person works in several departments or, for example, is a manager of a higher-level unit but is active in the project for a work group, you can adjust this accordingly in the table.

docs.title: Search applications and projects
docs.text:
You can use various filters on both the applications page and the project page to search through entries. Filter options such as project type, funding body, research areas or organisational units are available on the right-hand side of the page. However, there is also a specific filter for applications and projects.

On the left you see the filter option for applications, on the right for projects

You can filter applications separately by status, projects by timeline. There is also an extra filter for sub-projects.

For projects, you can also use the advanced search, which is similar in principle to the advanced activity search.

The advanced search page for projects

On the right you can save the searches you have created so that you can use them again. The MongoDB command of your search is displayed below the search field if you want to use it for other applications, such as report templates in OSIRIS.

docs.title: Project statistics
docs.text:
On the project overview page, you will find a button that will take you to various statistics relating to projects for your organisation. On the statistics page, you can adjust the period to which the following tables and figures relate.

Here you can specify the year or key date for which you want the statistics to be created

Various tables and figures are then displayed for the selected report year. The tables show you, for example, the number of projects and applications for the various categories. You will also see a list of all cooperation partners and how many projects they are involved in at your institution. To illustrate the diversity of the cooperation partners, a plot of the types and a world map with the location of the partners is provided here. If you move your mouse over the plots, you can download them as .png files by clicking on the camera symbol.

docs.title: Reports
docs.text:
The basic aim of OSIRIS is to facilitate regular reporting of all kinds and to record research activities at the institute in a regular and standardised manner. As different types of reports are generated at an institute, individual report templates can be created in OSIRIS. In OSIRIS, this role is assigned to editors and admins by default. In order for these reports, especially the quarterly reports, to be possible, the entries must be checked regularly by the users at the institute. In OSIRIS, statistics on all activities are also created and visualised. These can be exported and used for institute reports, but also for personalised reports.

However, it should also be mentioned that you do not need a template for every report. The advanced search or the filter functions on the All activities page also enable a specific list of entries that can then be exported.

docs.title: Quarterly reporting
docs.text: OSIRIS supports quarterly reporting with an extra function that the administration can activate under Settings → Functions. If this is the case, all users are reminded every 3 months to update, check and submit their activities for reporting.

docs.title: My year
docs.text: On the My year page, each user has an overview of their own activities, divided into categories. The linked page explains exactly what a reminder of the quarterly release looks like.

docs.title: Confirming the quarter
docs.text:
At the end of each quarter, users are prompted to release the quarter with the following message:

Notification displayed to each user at the end of each quarter

You are then taken to the My year page, which shows exactly which activities still require an action. You can then release the quarter here.

docs.title: Block activities
docs.text:
To prevent changes to activities, they can be locked. This can be useful, for example, if entries have already been included in reports. Locking activities is a right that is released by the administration and is usually carried out by the admin themselves or the editor. If you have the right to do so, the Block option will be displayed on the All activities page next to the Statistics button.

Lock time period: If you click on the lock button, you will be taken to this page. Here you can set a time period and block all activities (that were report-worthy) that fall within this time. They can then no longer be deleted or edited by users

Activities that are not report-worthy (e.g. online ahead of print, activities without affiliated authors) are not blocked. Blocked activities can only be edited or deleted by the editor or admin by default. This is made clear by the different display of a blocked activity.

Links: Editor/admin view of a closed activity; Right: User view. On the left, it is still possible to unlock or edit the activity; on the right, it can only be downloaded or added to the basket

docs.title: Create quarterly reports
docs.text:
To create quarterly reports, you can create a report template. This could look like this, for example:

Report editor for creating a template for quarterly reports

The template is kept very simple and only generates an aggregated table of all activity types. You can then select the period yourself under Reports.

Template of the quarterly report created above

You can choose here whether you want to export the report in a Word document or as HTML. If you select these settings, the report will look like this in the Word document, based on the building blocks that were put together in the report editor:

The 1st quarterly report for the year 2025 with an aggregated table for the three months

docs.title: Deactivate quarterly reports
docs.text: To deactivate the function, please contact the administration. They can deactivate quarterly reporting under Settings → Functions and the users will no longer receive any notifications.

docs.title: Report templates
docs.text:
The report templates function allows you to create customised reports to suit the needs of your institute. To do this, select the Report templates button in the admin area, give your template a name and click Create. You are now in the Report editor, which allows you to create your report using various building blocks. You can give your report a description here and specify the starting month and the duration in months. This can be adjusted later by the person creating the report. All changes must be saved so that they are applied to the finished preview (top right).

The report editor with your chosen title and space for a description

docs.title: Adding modules
docs.text:
Each element in your report is an individual building block, which means that a building block must be added for each heading, intermediate text and list of activities. There are different types of building blocks that can be selected by clicking on Add new building block.

The various blocks available to you in the report editor

Once created, the individual blocks can be moved in order using the dots on the left using drag & drop. You can always see what your report will look like by clicking on the Preview button at the top right. Simply go back in the browser to return to the editor.

docs.title: Variables
docs.text:
1.6.0

You can use the Variables button to add a field to your report template that can be filled in when generating the report. This makes the creation of reports more flexible. You can also use this variable in your text modules.

You can use this widget to add individual data fields to your report template, which can be customised when creating the report

To add a variable field to the report template, the following fields must be filled in:

  • Key: A unique identifier for the new data field (without spaces)
  • Type: The type of your field. You can choose between string, integer, float and boolean.
  • Name:** A unique name for your field. This is how your field is labelled in the template
  • Default value:** The value that is in the field by default

To include one of the variable fields in a text field, you can copy the necessary code directly under the default value.

docs.title: Text modules
docs.text:
You need text blocks to create headings and text elements in your report. You must create an individual block for each heading and text section, as the font for the entire text is defined in the field. For example, you create a text module with the font Heading 1 and one with Paragraph.

Create two text blocks to add different types of text to your report. Here you can also insert the code for your variable field to customise this part of the text

This is what your report currently looks like

If you now enter a different number in the Year field, for example, this will also change in the text below.

docs.title: Activity modules
docs.text:
To list all activities that were added to OSIRIS in the period selected above in the report, add an activity module. Here you can filter the posts to be listed using the IDs of the activities by entering the following MongoDB command in the field:

{"$and":[{"type":"publication"}]}

This command would list all activities with the ID publication, for example. If you also want to list all posters, create a new activity module and enter the following command:

{"$and":[{"type":"poster"}]}

If you want to use more complex filter options, it is best to use the advanced search. Here you can apply various filters and copy over the corresponding MongoDB command by clicking on Show filter. As an example, we will filter for the first name Martinique.

{"$and":[{"authors.first":"Martinique"}]}

docs.title: Activities (with additional field)
docs.text:
1.6.0

In addition to the listed activities, you can also use this module to add a list of activities with an additional field.

You can use this field to add a list of activities with an extra field. You can also sort the list according to a specific criterion

This is what the sorted list of activities looks like sorted by title in ascending order with the extra month field

You can also use Sort to sort your entries by a specific criterion in ascending or descending order.

docs.title: Table modules
docs.text:
You can add a table to your report that aggregates values according to certain criteria. You can also filter the activities here, using the same example as for the activities. Let's assume we want to have a table that lists the number of different activities over the last few years. To do this, we select type as the first aggregation (y-axis) and year as the second aggregation (x-axis).

The settings for a table module aggregated by "type" over years and the result

You can also choose here to limit the data to the period selected above. For example, an aggregation over the months is suitable here.

The settings for a table module aggregated by "type" over months for the selected period and the result

docs.title: Line modules
docs.text:
To separate the different entries more clearly in your report, you can add a dividing line with the line block.

Here you can see the arrangement of different blocks for your report

This is what your report looks like with the many building blocks

If you save the template like this, any user who is authorised to do so can create a report of this type in future. Under Export&Import → Reports, your template will look like this:

The created report template for the users with the variable fields looks like this

The start year, month and the duration in months that the report should cover can be set here. The variable fields can also be customised here. The finished report, which should resemble your preview in the editor, can be exported either as an MS Word document or as HTML.

docs.title: Statistics
docs.text:
If you are on the All activities page, you can access the Statistics via a button. Here OSIRIS offers you various tables that summarise the activities for the selected report period.

The statistics page with the option of configuring the report period

You will find the following statistics on this page:

  • Activities in the report period: The number of activities per category and type are listed here. The entries must have at least one affiliated author to be included in these statistics

  • Activities that started before the period: Here you will find a table with entries that started before the report period but ended during the period. This applies, for example, to courses or guests

  • Statistics on publications: You can also get a more detailed listing for publications on this page, in which the entries are counted according to the different types.

    Detailed statistics on publications in OSIRIS

    For example, you can see from the table how many journal articles were created without external persons and whether they are online (online ahead of print).

  • Number of open access publications: The activities in the report period are listed here according to various open access options

docs.title: Organisational units
docs.text:
Organisational units can help to map the organisational chart of your institution in OSIRIS and link employees directly to departments. You can find the organisational units in the menu on the left under People → Units.

Organisational units in OSIRIS, displayed as cards

On this page you can see all the units and sub-units created, the type of group, the number of members and the persons responsible. You can customise the display of the units at the top right.

The hierarchy view lists all units and the associated sub-units

In the hierarchy view, the subordinate groups are indicated by the corresponding indentation.

The organisation chart view offers you an interactive interface to view the units and sub-units

In the organisation chart view, you can display the associated sub-units by clicking on a unit. You can also choose at the top left whether you prefer a left-aligned view or an arrangement from top to bottom.

docs.title: Time-resolved links
docs.text:
In every organisation, employees may change departments or perhaps work in more than one unit. To record this, OSIRIS offers each employee the option of individually setting the period of time they work for the various units.

You can see your linked organisational units at the top right of your start page. Click on the pencil to go to the editing page

Here you can make individual settings for your organisational units

This page lists all the organisational units to which you have been assigned. If you are missing an organisational unit here, you can add more via Add unit.

Here you can add an organisational unit to your profile from a drop-down menu and directly enter the time period that you are or were active for this unit

If the unit to be added is not in the list, you can create a new organisational unit yourself if you have the rights to do so. If this is not the case, please contact your administration.

You can indicate here whether you are scientifically active in the unit or not. If you mark a unit as scientific on your profile, all research activities associated with you will be linked to this unit. These will then be listed on the organisational unit page under the Activities tab and the organisational unit will be displayed at the bottom right in the expanded view of the activity. However, this only applies to activities that fall within the period you specify here for the unit. If you set scientific to no, your activities will not be linked to the unit.

Here you can enter the exact period of time that you are or were active for the organisational unit

In this example, only the activities of this unit that took place after 28/08/2025 are added. Activities with a date before you joined this unit will not be linked.

docs.title: Edit units
docs.text: If you have the right to edit an organisational unit, you can make various settings using the edit button.

docs.title: General
docs.text:
You can add a description to the unit under the General tag. The standard formatting options are available in the text box.

General settings that you can make for the unit

You can also specify here whether the unit is displayed publicly and mark it as inactive if this unit is no longer active at the institute. The mandatory fields such as name and abbreviation can also be changed here, as can the colour. You can add a cost centre to this unit and link it to available research areas.

docs.title: Personnel
docs.text:
Under Personnel, you can adjust the managers and add further employees to the organisational unit.

Here you can add further managers and adjust the order

If you want to assign more people to the organisational unit, you can do this by clicking the Add person button. Here you can select the name from a drop-down menu, specify the start date of the affiliation and determine whether the person is scientifically affiliated or not. All added persons are listed under Directly assigned persons.

List of assigned persons with further setting options and the display of admin rights

In the list you can see which position the person has and since when they have been assigned to the unit. This date can only be customised by the person themselves. For actions, you can access the person's profile directly via the View button. You can also delete the person from the list here and give them editor rights to this organisational unit. If the person has administrator rights and therefore has editor rights to organisational units anyway, this will be displayed instead of the editor button.

docs.title: Research
docs.text:
Under this tab you can add research interests to the unit. Once you have added and saved a term, you can enter further details and link activities.

Adding research interests and linking them to activities

You can add a subtitle and a detailed description to your research interests, whereby all common formatting options are available to you here. In the search field, you can search for an activity that you would like to link to this interest. In contrast to linking to the unit itself, this is possible regardless of time - you can simply enter a term, press search and all activities found will be listed, which you can then add with one click. This link is not displayed in the extended activity view and is more for organising the literature.

docs.title: Delete
docs.text: Anyone who has editor rights for the unit can also delete it. It should be noted here that the removal of the unit cannot be undone and it is preferable to deactivate the unit under General.

docs.title: Add a new unit
docs.text:
You can create a new unit using the new unit button on the start page of the organisational units.

You can add new organisational units using this form

The following information is required:

  • Abbreviation of the unit
  • Type of group - double-click in the field to get suggestions
  • Name of the unit in English and German

You can also assign an individual colour to your new unit, which is then also selected for all sub-units. This is also clear from the fact that the colour selection is not available when adding a new sub-unit. So if you select a different unit instead of your institute under Superordinate group, you cannot assign a colour. In this step, you can only add the leading persons to your new unit, which are listed next to the crown icon in the map view of all units. Once you have created the unit, you can add more people.

docs.title: Adding a sub-unit
docs.text:
Once you have created your new unit, you can add new sub-units on the unit page.

Button for adding a new subunit

The form for adding a subunit is similar to the one shown above, except that the colour selection is not available, as the colour of the parent group is used here. If you still want to customise the parent group, you can do this via the drop-down menu.
